awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Understanding Formation and Removal Mechanisms of Micron-sized Non-metallic Inclusions in Steel Refining by Computational and Experimental Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Steel is one of the most versatile structural materials and has played a vital role in history and societal advancements. With the increasingly harsh environments demanded of steel, steelmaking requires strict engineering of chemistry, microstructure, and surface and interior quality characteristics of the ladle - the vessel used to transport and pour out molten steel.  In steelmaking, steel cleanliness, defined as the amount and size of non-metallic inclusions, is a critical issue and directly influences both subsequent processing steps and the quality of steel products. Micron-sized non-metallic inclusions are typically removed using argon and/or electromagnetic stirring.  These processes, though very difficult, are crucial to minimize such inclusions for lightweight high-performance components. The lack of fundamental knowledge of complex mechanisms and the ability to quantify the formation and transport of inclusions has hindered progress in the inclusions control in ladle refining. This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry project, collaboration between two institutions and two steel companies, pursues fundamental research on the formation and removal of micron-sized non-metallic inclusions during liquid steel refining in a ladle. The strong partnership in this project uniquely facilitates the know-how transfer to steel manufacturers with improved product quality and productivity, and therefore, increases the competitiveness of U.S. steel and relevant industries. The award will also provide students with opportunities of academic and industrial research and the project results will be showcased in outreach events to inspire K-16 students to pursue STEM education and careers.

To tackle the challenge associated with inclusions in a ladle refining process, this project aims at obtaining basic knowledge that will address such questions as: what are the mechanisms that generate micron-sized inclusion particles during argon and/or electromagnetic stirring; can flow shear instability at the slag/steel interface generate micron-sized inclusions and are slag-based inclusions the primary source to the total concentration of non-metallic inclusions in molten steel? The team will integrate computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling with laboratory water modeling and microfluidic experiments as well as on-site measurements in steel plants for fundamental studies. The outcomes of the project are expected to provide the following technical insights: (1) the relationships between flow instability at the steel-slag interface, slag-based inclusions, and the total amount of non-metallic inclusions, (2) the quantitative effects of stirring rate on the slag inclusion generation and entrainment, as well as inclusion flotation, (3) experimental technique and methodology for validating the CFD model, and (4) a high-fidelity comprehensive three-dimensional multiphase multi-scale, multi-physics, and multi-species CFD model for steel ladle refining, which can be employed to provide best practice guidance for steel cleanliness control and high-quality mass production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The control of nonmetallic inclusions is essential for the production of high-quality steels. Nonmetallic inclusions are small particles - oxides of aluminum, magnesium and calcium in this work - that are typically less than 5 microns in diameter. Though small and typically making up less than 0.01% of the volume of the steel, oxide inclusions can negatively affect steel processing and properties: by clustering together in the liquid steel, affecting the flow of the steel, and in solid steel by decreasing the deformability of the steel and causing surface imperfections.

In this project, we worked with modelers at Purdue Northwest and two steelmaking companies to study how the population of oxide inclusions in liquid steel responds to the refining conditions. Specifically, we wanted to detect inclusions that originate from slag. Slag is molten oxide that covers the top of the liquid steel during processing; the slag serves to remove both dissolved impurities (mainly sulfur) and oxide inclusions. Previous work showed that slag droplets can be mixed into the steel if the steel is stirred strongly. Our part of the project was to analyze steel samples that were produced under different stirring regimes, to find and quantify such slag-based inclusions.

We found that the current plant practice is effective at removing oxide inclusions from the steel: As the first image shows, the concentration of inclusions (here presented as an area fraction) steadily decreases during processing (with a jump in concentration at the last sample, likely because of late additions to the liquid steel). However, the main inclusions originated from the reaction of dissolved oxygen in steel with intentionally added aluminum, not from slag. We found that slag-based inclusions were very rare, accounting for a negligible area fraction for these analyses. Further analysis showed that slag-based inclusions were present, but were generally relatively large (typically 20-50 microns apparent diameter), and present in small numbers - around one in every 10 mm2 of sample surface, which makes these difficult to detect. The second image shows an example of such slag inclusions.

The large size of these inclusions appears to imply that the inclusions remain in the liquid steel for an extended time, allowing the inclusions to agglomerate and grow. This is interesting and a little surprising; it suggests that some mechanism retards removal of the inclusions. A likely mechanism is linked to the difference between the interfacial tension between steel and solid inclusions, and steel and liquid inclusions - this difference would promote removal of solid inclusions, but retard liquid inclusions.

Overall, the result of the investigation is that slag-based inclusions are present in liquid steel, but these are larger than we expected, which means that aspects of how these droplets originate from the slag and remain in the liquid steel are still unknown.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Petrus C Pistorius
